ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the theoretical frameworks of Indigenous politics as well as Indigenous studies as a whole. The course highlighted the similarities and differences in struggles for different Indigenous groups around the world.

I gained insights about Indigenous Politics and differing perspectives within it. While taking the course, I learned and read a lot of material that broadened my knowledge and formed my beliefs of Indigenous Politics. Most of the readings were very insightful and presented perspectives and information that were new.
This course cultivated my capacity to deal more substantively with the great array of global Indigenous perspectives, voices and futures.

I learned so much about the struggles faced by the Indigenous populations of America, Canada and Australia and the multiple approaches taken to dealing with the political, cultural and environmental violence these populations face.
A greater understanding and appreciation for indigenous studies
Understanding of decolonial studies, resurgence, Black and Indigenous critiques, economic theory, race relations, history, Indigeneity, etc

I learned so much from this class. We looked at key thinkers in decolonial studies and covered many aspects of Indigenous people's relationship to the settler state  the ongoing structure of colonialism and dispossession, social/human geographies, biopolitics, infrastructures, water politics, gendered violence, resurgence and hopes for the future.

I learned central theory to Indigenous studies including discussing settler colonialism, difference of indigeneity, slow violence, breath and air, feminism, infrastructure, and biopolitics. I have learnt so much from this semester also about the overlaps of Indigenous Studies and Black Studies and other forms of solidarities. I also enjoyed how we discussed not just Indigenous struggles of North America but also in the Pacific, Oceania, and Palestine.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Engagement is a necessity as it is a small seminar but all of the material is engaging and it seems like most of the class is regularly engaging out of genuine interest.
One strength is how the course is structured. There is a very clear structure through themes that all flow well into each other. There were no clear weaknesses.

This course is an example of one of the few  if not out-and-out the first time, fully  that I have felt that Indigenous lives and voices had a space to breathe here in the context of a seminar room. It is well-structured, thorough, thought-provoking, open to disagreement and discussion, and insightfully, powerfully and compassionately delivered.

I honestly could not suggest doing anything differently. The class was highly engaging and Professor Hobart was incredible about initiating class discussion and creating a comfortable environment that kept us all engaged.
I loved the format of the class and enjoyed the discussions every week. The readings were insightful an interesting an I felt they supported my learning of this class really well
I love the syllabus. It includes lots of Black and Indigenous thinkers, especially women. I think it could involve aboriginal thinkers and queer thinkers a bit more
I thought the course was fantastic and I learned so much from it. However, there was a ton of reading for each week and some readings were just pretty dense/hard to get through.

Professor Hobart is an amazing professor. She was incredibly understanding of her students and was very thoughtful about the questions that she posed for discussion. I also appreciated the time that she took to explain the context for historical events and for theory, allowing me to get a better grasp of the content. Additionally, the readings and the content we had in class was all purposefully picked by Professor Hobart.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course might be my favorite at Yale! I loved the diversity of material and humanity of our discussions and learning.

I would definitely recommend this course. Everything about it was fantastic; the content, the incremental work done toward a research paper and the way in which Professor Hobart kept the class constantly engaged.
Yes, if you are interested at all in indigenous studies or race relations in America or internationally
Yes, especially sophomores. This course is a fantastic introduction to Indigenous studies / settler colonial studies.
Yes, Professor Hobart is fantastic and you cover so much together throughout the semester. It's a must-take course for anyone interested in ER&M.

bsolutely! This course was incredibly enriching and gave me so many more tools to use for my life and future classes that I take. Please take this course if you are at all interested in Indigenous resistance movements and theory.
